Basic Electronics.name: Ohm's Law
Basic Electronics.description: Ohm's Law defines the linear relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in an electrical circuit.

Basic Electronics.name: Power
Basic Electronics.description: Electrical power represents the rate at which energy is consumed or supplied in a circuit. It can be expressed in different forms using Ohm's Law.

Basic Electronics.name: Energy
Basic Electronics.description: Energy consumed or supplied in a circuit is the product of power and the time for which it flows.

Basic Electronics.name: AC Power (Apparent Power)
Basic Electronics.description: Apparent power in AC circuits is the product of RMS voltage and RMS current, representing the total power flowing in the circuit.

Basic Electronics.name: AC Power (Active Power)

variables.φ: Phase angle between voltage and current (radians or degrees)

Basic Electronics.description: Active power is the real power consumed in an AC circuit. It is the component of apparent power that performs useful work.

Basic Electronics.name: Power Factor

variables.φ: Phase angle between voltage and current

Basic Electronics.description: Power factor is the cosine of the phase angle between voltage and current. It indicates the efficiency of power usage in AC circuits.

Basic Electronics.name: Heating Effect of Current (Joule’s Law)
Basic Electronics.description: Joule’s Law states that the heat produced in a conductor due to current flow is proportional to the square of the current, the resistance, and the time of flow.

Basic Electronics.name: Law of Mass Action

variables.n: Concentration of electrons in the conduction band (cm^-3)
variables.p: Concentration of holes in the valence band (cm^-3)

Basic Electronics.description: The Law of Mass Action states that the product of electron and hole concentrations in a semiconductor is constant at a given temperature, equal to the square of the intrinsic carrier concentration. For intrinsic semiconductors, n = p = n_i.

Basic Electronics.name: Carrier Concentration in Intrinsic Semiconductor
Basic Electronics.description: The intrinsic carrier concentration (n_i) in a semiconductor depends on temperature and the bandgap energy. It increases with temperature due to thermal excitation of electrons across the bandgap, and decreases with larger bandgap energy.

Basic Electronics.name: Law of Mass Action (N-type Semiconductor)
Basic Electronics.description: In an N-type semiconductor, electrons are the majority carriers with concentration approximately equal to the donor concentration. The minority carrier (hole) concentration is given by the mass action law as p ≈ n_i² / N_D.

Basic Electronics.name: Law of Mass Action (P-type Semiconductor)
Basic Electronics.description: In a P-type semiconductor, holes are the majority carriers with concentration approximately equal to the acceptor concentration. The minority carrier (electron) concentration is given by the mass action law as n ≈ n_i² / N_A.

Basic Electronics.name: Carrier Mobility
Basic Electronics.description: Carrier mobility is a measure of how quickly charge carriers (electrons or holes) move through a semiconductor when subjected to an electric field.

Basic Electronics.name: Drift Velocity
Basic Electronics.description: Drift velocity is the average velocity of charge carriers in a semiconductor due to an external electric field. It is directly proportional to carrier mobility and the applied field.

Basic Electronics.name: Current Density
Basic Electronics.description: Current density is the amount of electric current flowing per unit cross-sectional area of a conductor or semiconductor.

Basic Electronics.name: Electrical Conductivity
Basic Electronics.description: The electrical conductivity of a semiconductor depends on both electron and hole contributions. It increases with carrier concentration and carrier mobility.

Basic Electronics.name: Drift Current Density
Basic Electronics.formula: J_{drift} = \rho_e v_e + \rho_h v_h = (n \mu_n + p \mu_p) q E = \sigma E
Basic Electronics.description: Drift current density in a semiconductor arises from the motion of both electrons and holes under an applied electric field. It can be expressed in terms of charge densities and drift velocities, carrier mobilities and concentrations, or simply as conductivity multiplied by the electric field.

Basic Electronics.name: Drift Current
Basic Electronics.formula: I_{drift} = I_{n(drift)} + I_{p(drift)} = q \cdot A \cdot (n \mu_n + p \mu_p) \cdot E
Basic Electronics.description: The total drift current in a semiconductor is the sum of the electron and hole drift currents. It depends on the carrier concentrations, mobilities, applied electric field, and the cross-sectional area of the material.

Basic Electronics.name: Drift Current Density
Basic Electronics.description: Drift current density is the electric current per unit area in a semiconductor due to the motion of charge carriers under an applied electric field.

Basic Electronics.name: Total Current Density in a Semiconductor
Basic Electronics.formula: J_{total} = \sigma E + q (D_n \nabla n - D_p \nabla p)
Basic Electronics.description: The total current density in a semiconductor has two components: the drift current due to the applied electric field (σE) and the diffusion current due to carrier concentration gradients. The electron diffusion term contributes qD_n∇n, while the hole diffusion term contributes −qD_p∇p.

Basic Electronics.name: Junction Capacitance (Depletion Capacitance)

variables.\\varepsilon_r: Relative permittivity (dielectric constant) of the semiconductor (dimensionless)

Basic Electronics.description: The junction capacitance in a semiconductor PN junction behaves like a parallel plate capacitor, where the depletion region acts as the dielectric layer. It is inversely proportional to the depletion width and directly proportional to the junction area and the semiconductor permittivity.

Basic Electronics.name: Built-in Potential of a PN Junction
Basic Electronics.description: The built-in potential, also called the contact potential or potential barrier, is the equilibrium voltage that develops across the depletion region of a PN junction due to diffusion of carriers. It prevents further diffusion and balances the drift current caused by the electric field in the depletion region.

Basic Electronics.name: Forward Bias Voltage of a PN Junction
Basic Electronics.description: The forward bias voltage applied to a PN junction must overcome the built-in potential barrier. The total voltage across the junction also includes the voltage drops due to the diode's internal resistance and the external load resistance.

example.problem: \text{An AC voltage of peak value 20V is connected in series with a silicon diode and load resistance of 500Ω. If the forward resistance of the diode is 10Ω, find the peak current and peak output voltage through the diode}.
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{(i) Practical Case:} \\
V_F &= V_B + I_p (r_f + R_L) \\
20 &= 0.7 + I_p (10 + 500) \\
20 - 0.7 &= I_p (510) \\
19.3 &= 510 I_p \\
I_p &= \tfrac{19.3}{510} \\
I_p &\approx \boxed{37.8 \, \text{mA}} \\
\\
V_{P_{out}} &= I_p \times R_L \\
&= 37.8 \, \text{mA} \times 500 \, \Omega \\
&= \boxed{18.9 \, \text{V}} \\
\\
\textbf{(ii) Ideal Case:} \\
\text{For an ideal diode, set } V_B = 0, \, r_f = 0 \\
V_F &= I_p R_L \\
I_p &= \tfrac{V_F}{R_L} = \tfrac{20}{500} \\
I_p &= \boxed{40 \, \text{mA}} \\
\\
V_{P_{out}} &= I_p \times R_L \\
&= 40 \, \text{mA} \times 500 \, \Omega \\
&= \boxed{20 \, \text{V}}
\end{aligned}

Basic Electronics.name: Output Voltage Across Load Resistance
Basic Electronics.description: The output voltage across a load resistance is obtained from Ohm's law as the product of the current flowing through the load and the load resistance.

example.problem: \text{A diode circuit has a forward current of 25 mA flowing through a load resistance of 400 Ω. Calculate the output voltage across the load}.
